author: pcgeek86
body:
Something that might be useful for people using software containers, such as Docker / OCI or rkt, would be to include some debugging information to `$PSVersionTable`, to determine whether or not the PowerShell instance is running inside a software container. This may aid in debugging by providing additional, contextual information about the PowerShell process.

Cheers,
**Trevor Sullivan**
Docker Captain
Microsoft MVP: Cloud & Data Center Management
https://trevorsullivan.net
https://twitter.com/pcgeek86

comments.author: phwelo
comments.body: Could also use an $env variable to give us something to work with, which is more of a Docker-y way of presenting that

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body: @phwelo Possibly a PS variable, but `$env` variables are explicitly [environment variables](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environment_variable). Unless there's already an environment variable for knowing if you're in a container, I don't think that's applicable here.

comments.author: phwelo
comments.body: My point was more that a container is describing the environment more than it is the Powershell thread. Overall it doesn't matter to me as long as I can differentiate though!

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body:
@phwelo oh, gotcha, that make sense. 

I'm hoping that .NET Core 2.0 exposes something in System.Environment to help with this. But otherwise, it might be Docker's responsibility, as you say.

title: Add debugging information to determine if running in container
